comment: You should be proud that you've created a wealth of knowledge, that even 11 years later, is still being used by students (like myself)
Soooo lol  What metals are safe to use when making alkaline water?
wow simply super thank you very much
This saved my ass... thanks alot
Bro , I want their chemical properties with other elements ,can u help me with that plss??
Ca(OH)2 is not considered a molecule, it's an ionic compound, atleast where i learn chemistry you get an F for saying it's a molecule.

Do you enjoy going around my videos correcting the little things ;-) but if we are to be technical, a molecule is a collection of atoms that are bonded together via electric forces. and ionic bonds are exactly that...  we do call molecules that are made of ionic bonds ionic compounds, but its not incorrect to call an ionic compound a molecule.  So next time your teacher fails you for calling an ionic compound a molecule, you should tell them to study a bit of physics. Remember the entire theory of bonding stems from understanding physics and the laws that govern the microscopic world. There is really no distinction between "polar covalent, non-polar covalent and ionic bonds" in the sense that they are all a result of electric forces. The only difference is in the distribution of electron density around the atoms. But ultimately its the same type of electric bond.   ;-)
